==Free Unix-like operating systems==
==Free Unix-like operating systems==

[[Image:Ubuntu 8.04.png|thumb|250 px|Linux is a modern Unix-like system (Ubuntu Hardy Heron pictured)]]
+
[[Image:Ubuntu.png|thumb|250 px|Linux is a modern Unix-like system (Ubuntu Hardy Heron pictured)]]
In 1983, [[Richard Stallman]] announced the [[GNU]] project, an ambitious effort to create a [[free software]] [[Unix-like]] system; "free" in that everyone who received a copy would be free to use, study, modify, and redistribute it. The GNU project's own kernel development project, [[GNU Hurd]], had not produced a working kernel, but the [[Linux kernel]] was released as free software in 1992 under the [[GNU General Public License]]. In addition to their use in the [[Linux]] operating system, many GNU packages â such as the [[GNU Compiler Collection]] (and the rest of the [[GNU toolchain]]), the [[glibc|GNU C library]] and the [[Coreutils|GNU core utilities]] â have gone on to play central roles in other free Unix systems as well.
In 1983, [[Richard Stallman]] announced the [[GNU]] project, an ambitious effort to create a [[free software]] [[Unix-like]] system; "free" in that everyone who received a copy would be free to use, study, modify, and redistribute it. The GNU project's own kernel development project, [[GNU Hurd]], had not produced a working kernel, but the [[Linux kernel]] was released as free software in 1992 under the [[GNU General Public License]]. In addition to their use in the [[Linux]] operating system, many GNU packages â such as the [[GNU Compiler Collection]] (and the rest of the [[GNU toolchain]]), the [[glibc|GNU C library]] and the [[Coreutils|GNU core utilities]] â have gone on to play central roles in other free Unix systems as well.
